author: ELAINE GLUSAC
title: In Transit: Monday’s Travel News: American Merges Systems; Fare Deals to Europe.
text: Continue reading the main story Finnair also just announced a fall sale from Boston, Los Angeles, Miami, New York and other United States airports. For bookings before July 31, round-trip, economy fares to St. Petersburg start at $585, Tel Aviv from $840, Stockholm from $995 and Paris from $1,125. A seven-day stay is required, and travel must take place Aug. 16 through Dec. 14. Finnair is part of the Oneworld alliance with American Airlines. KLM and Air France are members of the SkyTeam alliance with Delta Air Lines. SAN FRANCISCO’S NEW NEIGHBORHOOD MUSEUM The new Tenderloin Museum in San Francisco, which opened late last week, aims to celebrate the still gritty neighborhood and its artists and activists with exhibitions, walking tours and evening events. A district once synonymous with vice, the Tenderloin offered a sanctuary for Asian refugees after the Vietnam War, incubated the gay and transgender movements and drew artists including the Grateful Dead, Miles Davis and Dashiell Hammett, subjects covered in the 3,200-square-foot museum’s permanent exhibition. In addition, the museum serves as a starting point for daily one-hour walking tours of the Tenderloin ($10) led by locals. Sites include the garages where Davis and the Dead recorded albums, single-room-occupancy hotels where Muhammad Ali and Sugar Ray Robinson boxed, and sites key to the LGBT rights movement. A 90-minute evening tour will be offered on Thursdays for adults only ($20). “We’re trying to encourage understanding of the current Tenderloin by walking through the neighborhood and really making people feel connected,” said Randy Shaw, a board member at the museum. Upcoming events include film screenings, lectures and poetry readings. BOSTON TEA PARTY TICKETS Each December, history interrupts holiday preparations in Boston with the Dec. 16 re-enactment of the Boston Tea Party. Tickets went on sale this month for the annual event organized by the Old South Meeting House and Boston Tea Party Ships & Museum . Admission to the Old South Meeting House, site of “The Meeting of the Body of the People,” in which colonial actors representing Samuel Adams, John Hancock and Paul Revere confront Loyalists, are limited to 600 spectators who are encouraged to join in the debate. Fife and drum players head to the wharf, where is a staging of the 1773 Boston Tea Party, featuring the dumping of East India tea into the bay. Tickets cost $15. Prices rise to $20 in September and $25 in November. Loading...
